results.title: Women: three views
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
Interviews with three Aboriginal women who have chosen to be activists in the struggle for their peoples’ rights. Mum Shirl has been an activist since the late sixties, including initiating the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in the early seventies. Since then she has become disillusioned with political processes in Australia and now chooses to work directly with Aboriginal people in prisons. Marcia Langton works for the Central Lands Council in Alice Springs and she talks passionately on behalf of Aboriginal peoples’ struggles for land rights and dignity. Maryanne Bin-Sallik works within government departments using established political means to argue for the rights of Aborigines. Though choosing very different ways to express their activism, we see that all three women are united in their commitment to work towards an autonomous and central role for Aborigines in Australian politics and culture.

results.title: Women, wine and wellness: alcohol and your body
results.brief_description: Part 1 in a series about alcohol and its effects on women’s wellbeing. Even with allowances for the basic differences in size between men an women, women are more susceptible to intoxication and diseases of the liver than are men. Women may be trapped in a dangerous cycle when they combine the empty calories of alcohol with an unblanced diet. Even more serious are the results of alcohol abuse which include loss of judgement and addiction. No other credits available.

results.title: Women, drugs and alcohol
results.creator_credit: John MacDonald, J. Gary Mitchell and MTI Teleprograms
results.brief_description: Illustrates the realities of drugs and alcohol abuse among women, with a special emphasis on prescription drugs. Presents vital information on the nature and scope of the problem as seen by experts in the field of medicine, pharmacology and psychology. Explores the situation of the woman abuser through interviews and discussions. Narrated by Jessica Walter.

results.title: Women working in the media
results.creator_credit: Don Fitzsimmons, Julie Sheehan, Sabina Baltrukomis and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Pat Walter, a video camera operator, Julie Copeland, a radio broadcaster and producer, and Lina Caneva, a TV and radio journalist, discuss their experiences as women working in the male-dominated TV and radio industry.

results.title: Women Without Shadows
results.brief_description: A series of interviews which try to establish the current role of the woman in the Saudi society in relation with the recent past.

constellations_other.name: VFX to fantasy and freedom
constellations_other.description: Founded in Sydney, and now with offices worldwide, Animal Logic are an Academy Award-winning VFX and animation studio whose job is to bring the impossible to life. And they're in good company with these other artists and filmmakers.

results.title: Women with rheumatoid arthritis: "Don't take us at face value"
results.creator_credit: Steve Macdonald and Arthritic Women's Task Force
results.brief_description: An information package designed to assist HACC (Home and Community Care) administrators and service providers in caring for women with rheumatoid arthritis. It addresses aspects of the experience of the disease, the side effects of treatment, the impact on self image and self esteem, barriers to receiving HACC services and the need to increase community awareness. Accompanied by an 11p. Supplementary Booklet and the 65p. “Women with rheumatoid arthritis: a home and community care demonstration project report, 1989.”
results.title_for_label: Women with rheumatoid arthritis: “Don’t take us at face value”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Steve Macdonald and Arthritic Women’s Task Force

results.title: Women want...
results.creator_credit: George Kaczender, Robert Baylis, International Cinemedia Center and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Using a combination of staged scenarios, documentary and interview, this information film takes a probing look at the socio-cultural, political, legal and business status of Canadian women over the years, making clear the inconsistencies they have always faced. The film makes the point that the struggle for the liberation of women is not a struggle against men but, rather, a struggle for equality and self-determination. It is a film that demands the liberation of both sexes, and, as such, should be seen by both.

results.title: Women today
results.brief_description: The German woman of today is emancipated, having the same education, professional chances and rights as the German man. There are many problems, however, connected with her role in today’s society.

results.title: Women on the verge of a nervous breakdown = Mujeres al borde de un ataque nervios
results.creator_credit: Pedro Almodovar, El Deseo S. A. and Laurenfilm
results.brief_description: Pepa, an actress, is tough, sexy and desperate. Her longtime lover and male chauvinist rat, Ivan, to whom she is pregnant, has walked out leaving only a bland message on her answering machine. Pepa simply cannot resist fighting back and is determined to find Ivan. She decides to sublet her apartment. The first couple to look at the apartment are Carlos, Ivan’s 20 year old son, whom Pepa had never known about, and Marisa, Carlos’ uptight virgin fiancee. To make things even more delirious, Pepa’s best friend, Candella, comes looking for refuge from the police. Into this maelstrom of tension walks Lucia, Ivan’s ex-wife… A raucously funny depiction of melodramatic and crazy women who get their revenge any way they can. Stars Carmen Maura and Antonio Banderas. In Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Women on the march: the struggle for equal rights
results.creator_credit: Douglas Tunstell, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Part 1: A film record of women at the turn of the century and of the suffragette movement’s struggle for equal rights. Spearheaded by women like Emmeline Pankhurst, the movement was characterized by imprisonment, demonstrations, and a great following of men and women. Women of all classes, women working during the war, overseas and in North America, are presented in this fine documentary. Part 2: Made in 1958, this part of the film begins and ends in praise of women’s acquisition of the vote. In between is a rendition of all the “equal” activities of women (and even more than equal in factory work). Much footage is devoted to the UN Status of Women committee, whose mandate does not extend beyond equal political rights under the law.
